Given v vs. t obtain x vs. t
a="1/2*0.75 *t^2"
An object is moving along a straight line. Its velocity as a function of time is shown in the figure below.
Part a) Assuming that at t = 0 the object is at the origin answer the questions below. (In all the parts you need to express the answer in meters but you do not need to enter the units in the box).
1. What is the mathematical representation of the object's position as a function of time for times 0 < t < 20 (in seconds)? Use the variable t in your answer. Omit units.
\(x(t)=\)
2. Where is the object at time t = 30 s? \(x(t=30)=\)
3. Where is the object at time t = 40 s? \(x(t=40)=\)
4. Where is the object at time t = 50 s? \(x(t=50)=\)
5. Where is the object at time t = 80 s? \(x(t=80)=\)
Part b) On a piece of paper do a qualitative plot of the position as a function of time.
Part c) Check your plot. Watch the construction of the plot of x vs. t by Mr Dave Sim The Physics Café
Note 1: The variable s is the object's position.
Note 2: The gradient of s - t refers to the time derivative of s: \( v = \frac{ds}{dt}\)
Note 3: The area under the curve of v vs t is the object's position.
